entry.title: Not satisfied with Sithalapakkam’s Jai Biriyani

link.title: Not satisfied with Sithalapakkam's Jai Biriyani

entry.content:
When you take the petrol bunk left turn while you cross Sithalapakkam’s panchayat office, you will see Jai Biriyani. Biriyani there is cheap, I think it costs ₹110/-. It tastes moderate, the first time I bought the chicken was bit rubbery, possibly not cooked fully? I am not sure.

So the second time I bought kushka and chicken 65, it cost ₹170/-, there was a small piece in kushka which excited me, the chicken 65 was deep fried, came with few pieces of sliced onion and one eighth piece of lemon. It was more enjoyable than biriyani as this time there was no rubbery chicken, but that day I had a mild stomach upset.

I hope Jai Biriyani improves. But I don’t think I will be buying from them again. The staff over there are all Tamil, so you won’t have language difficulty, they are respectful. I hope they improve quality.

entry.title: Elon Musk and my style of work

link.title: Elon Musk and my style of work

entry.content:
Elon Musk - The evil boss you must avoid.

I push for 16 hour work week, with four-hour work days. I strongly feel that knowledge workers should have life, should spend time with their family and loved ones, think and reflect, should get new ideas. This I feel will cultivate a healthy brain and will ultimately increase productivity of the company.

What Elon Musk doing in Twitter looks very evil to me. For some reason even people of science and creativity, when they move to management, they become task masters without brains. They seem to forget where true productivity lies.

There are times when I finished coding for a sprint (2 weeks long one) in 2 hours, but yes all those other paper work does cost more time, but the core issue only takes two hours. There are times when even the sprint got over I haven’t started coding as the details were murky, or my understanding was not right. I understood a lot of things when I am away from keyboard, something works in your brains background while you enjoy life, all of a sudden most elegant solution pops up, and you implement it, and it works!

Somehow management people never seems to understand it, their view of knowledge work is like viewing a repetitive work in a factory. Humans are like automated robots to them. If a robot can drive 1000 bolts in an hour, then it must drive 4000 in four hours. In my view a human or biological system is not like that. We get tired, we get energized, we sometimes find work rewarding, and sometimes boring.

I am not worried about Twitters future, or its success or failure, I am long time user of Diaspora, I use Mastodon, and I have deleted my Facebook long ago. I am worried about the dangerous precedent Elon is setting in the I.T industry. With people like him, the industry will be populated by mindless ‘yes boss’ human bots who are there for a paycheck, than for the passion of coding.
entry.summary: Elon Musk - The evil boss you must avoid.

entry.title: Vadacurry in Hotel Archana Bhavan in Sithalapakkam is good

link.title: Vadacurry in Hotel Archana Bhavan in Sithalapakkam is good

entry.content:
You turn left from the Sithalapakkam Panchayat office (the petrol bunk bend) and head towards Shankarapuram, you will see a hotel called Archana Bhavan. That hotel is not good for dining, it has got not fully closed space, you need to dine almost on platform. The ambience in front of the hotel is also not good. Dog and cow shit littered before the hotel and none bothers to keep it clean. I have seen dirty pigs grazing just meters away from the hotel.

There is no proper running water wash basin in the hotel, you will see a sink on the platform, near that a bucket containing dirty water with food particles floating in it and a tumbler near it, that’s the water they give you to wash hands. Once I went there to dine, and seeing this I returned.

What is good however is their vadacurry if you get parcel of it, it costs ₹20/-. It’s nice oily and tasty. I have tried their idyappams with their vadacurry, it’s awesome.

entry.title: Slack is a distraction
entry.content:
So I had to do a ticket in office today, I started it and within two hours I finished it. This work was estimated for a week or more. I couldn’t believe what had happened. I submitted a pull request, deployed code to our testing server and only in mid day I realized I had never turned on Slack.

When Slack or any other messenger is turned on you are conscious about it. You expect someone to ping, this anticipation slows you down, drains some part of your cognition. When someone pings your attention moves, and rather than check the ping, you also check other channels and stuff. Then your brain stars to think in various pathways, your concentration is drawn out away from solving the issue.

I turned on Slack, there was a pull request comment, though it was minor I think I took kind of 4 hours because I was looking at messages and interacting etc.

If one has to be productive, I strongly recommend turning off Slack, Zulip, Rocket Chat, Telegram, WhatsApp or any other messenger, finish your task and then check distraction stuff in your slack time. But yes this does not work for all, many of you are paid to respond to distractions you get professionally, but for those who can be productive, be productive.
